Award.AwardTitle: LSAMP BD: University of Wisconsin-Madison WiscAMP

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and competitiveness of STEM graduate students from historically underrepresented minority populations, with emphasis on STEM doctoral matriculation and completion.

The 2018-2020 Wisconsin LSAMP BD (WiscAMP-BD) program will recruit twelve (12) alumni from LSAMP institutions nationwide for STEM postbaccalaureate studies at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The program leverages activities of the institution's Graduate Engineering Research Scholars Program (GERS), the Graduate Research Scholars Program in the College of Agricultural and Life Sciences (SciMed GRS) and the Teaching, Mentoring and Research for Science (TEAM Science) programs, including faculty mentored research and communities of practice. Twenty-four BD participants are currently matriculating in STEM doctoral programs at the institution. Student support in the form of stipends and cost of education are provided for two years for each student. The institution commits to assisting the students financially through completion of the STEM doctoral program.

Evaluative activities will assess outcomes of students' accomplishments relating to retention, degree completion, and career progress. Social psychological outcomes related to career goals and expectations related to STEM identity development will also be assessed. Outcomes will be disseminated broadly through the institution's website, scholarly journals, and presentations at STEM professional conferences. These efforts will increase the diversity of STEM academic leadership and contribute to the growing literature on broadening participation in STEM at the graduate and post-graduate level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability of the United States to protect its national interests and remain competitive on a global scale requires a domestic workforce with advanced degree training in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Yet, graduate education in STEM is marked by a persistent absence of certain ethnic/racial groups and in some disciplines women of all backgrounds. Despite the need for diverse researchers, many excellent students from backgrounds that are underrepresented in STEM begin their graduate studies in a STEM discipline, but leave before completing their degrees. The LSAMP BD: University of Wisconsin-Madison (WiscAMP) project addressed the need to increase the diversity of an advanced degree STEM workforce by:

  • Recruiting a cohort of 12 excellent students who graduated with baccalaureate degrees in STEM from Louis Stokes Alliance from Minority Participation institutions across the country
  • Pairing students with experienced faculty advisors who have robust research programs and are committed to supporting students with mentorship and research funding through five years of graduate study
  • Providing professional development seminars, social opportunities with a diverse community of peers, and access to a network of culturally responsive faculty mentors

At the end of its award period, the project has successfully retained 11 out of 12 underrepresented minority students in STEM doctoral training programs. One of the 11 students one has already completed his PhD and secured a postdoc at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. Of the 10 students who remain in doctoral programs, all have completed their qualifying exams and five are already dissertators. One student was selected for a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship.

Broader Impacts: The WiscAMP-BD project outcomes reflect the collective commitment of faculty, graduate training program staff and administrative leadership to the national effort to broaden participation in STEM and diversify the professoriate. The collaborations between programs, faculty and staff have led to more integrated and consistent professional development opportunities across graduate training programs. The long-term outcome of the project will be to increase the ethnic/racial diversity of leaders throughout academic science and engineering.  Increasing the diversity of academic leadership will promote greater diversity in all STEM areas and foster research excellence and innovation.

Intellectual Merit: An earlier implementation of the WiscAMP-BD project included an evaluation component that provided valuable evidence of the importance of programs to retain underrepresented minority students in STEM graduate programs. A survey of students who were participating in WiscAMP-BD and similar programs found that minority graduate students in these programs were more likely than their counterparts to believe they belonged in their discipline and to value the importance of ethnic and gender diversity in their field of research. These results are consistent with attitudes and beliefs that will lead to persistence in research career pathways and have been disseminated at regional and national conferences. The strong progress and high retention of the WiscAMP-BD students in the current project lends weight to this claim.
